definition:
Benzodiazepines
(BZD, BDZ, BZs), sometimes called 'benzos', are a class of
psychoactive drugs whose core chemical structure is the fusion of a
benzene ring and a diazepine ring. As depressants—drugs which lower
brain activity—they are prescribed to treat conditions such as
&%Anxiety, &%Insomnia, and &%Seizures. The first benzodiazepine,
chlordiazepoxide (Librium), was discovered accidentally by Leo
Sternbach in 1955 and was made available in 1960 by Hoffmann–La Roche,
which soon followed with diazepam (Valium) in 1963. By 1977,
benzodiazepines were the most prescribed medications globally; the
introduction of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), among
other factors, decreased rates of prescription, but they remain
frequently used worldwide.[from Wikipedia]
